holdings.text: The inam comprised only the melwaram and not the kudiwaram.

anchor.surface_text: there is no proof that the kudiwaram was the subject of the inam. All admissible matter points to the conclusion that the melwaram alone was the subject of the grant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admissible evidence including village accounts, Inam statements, and Fair Register show only poruppu (melwaram) granted; secondary copies of leases inadmissible; no presumption of kudiwaram inclusion per precedent.

holdings.text: The inam was a service inam granted for archaka service in the temple, attached to the office, and liable to resumption upon alienation, not a personal inam.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the learned District Judge, Madurai, that this was a personal inam to, an individual was erroneous and the High Court was right in reversing it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inam Fair Register describes as Devadayam for archaka puja service, entered as Sthanikars; Ex.A-3 as Devedayam for temple; Ex.A-10 confirms enjoyment tied to service; precedent distinguishes service inams.

holdings.text: Section 44B of the Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927 is valid and intra vires the provincial legislature; resumption under it is lawful.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Provincial competence over land revenue, endowments per Devolution Rules; not forfeiture but resumption of conditional grant; 32&33 Vict c.29 validates deeds but creates no inviolable contract; sustained by s.292 GOI 1935.

holdings.text: No adverse possession or limitation applies against the government to resume or assess inam lands.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in Boddapalli Jagannadham and Subramaniam Chettiar holds no limitation period for government to exercise prerogative of assessment or resumption.

holdings.text: Inam Fair Register constitutes a landmark official declaration of supreme importance on inam nature.

anchor.surface_text: the Inam Fair Register of 1863, does not mention the name of the original grantee... In the absence of positive and proper evidence to the contrary such declaration must possess supreme importance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Result of detailed Inam Commission inquiry; treated as act of state per Privy Council and SC precedents like Arunachalam Chetty.

holdings.text: Resumption under s.44B(1) applies to inams granted for temple service/office remuneration, resumable on alienation or non-performance, distinguishing personal burdened grants.

anchor.surface_text: Section 44-B inserted by the Madras Hindu Religious -Endowment Amendment Act 1934...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Bheemsena Rao: restricted to service inams where income mainly for service; pre-s.44B governed by Board Standing Order 54 allowing resumption/assessment.

holdings.text: No presumption that inam grant includes kudiwaram.

anchor.surface_text: In Venkata v. Sitamadu it was held by the Privy Council that there was no presumption in law that an inam grant... did not include the kudiwaram.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has relied upon a decision of the Madras High Court in Rasa Kondan v. Janaki Ammal.  1  Inams are of various kinds. They are classified on the basis of companycession in land revenue, that is to ,say, whether the whole of the land revenue is remitted or a part, or whether the land is held subject to a payment of money.

precedents.citation: P. B. Bheemsena Rao v. Sirigiri Paddayella Reddi and others.  1

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  1  of s. 44-B was the subject of interpretation in P. B. Bheemsena Rao v. Sirigiri Paddayella Reddi and others.  1  The question then was whether s. 44-B 1  companyered a grant of land burdened with service as against a grant for an ,office to be remunerated by the use of land but resumable when the, service was number performed.

precedents.case_name: P. B. Bheemsena Rao v. Sirigiri Paddayella Reddi and others
precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of s.44B(1): distinction between grant of land burdened with service vs proper service inam for office
precedents.cited_holding: s.44-B(1) includes resumable inams where whole income required for service, not large personal inams with slight service; grant to officeholder resumable if service not performed

anchor.surface_text: We have considered the two views and are of opinion that the High Court has reached the right conclusion on the admissible evidence on record. Civil Appeal No. 69 of 1965 must thus fail and this finding by us will be read in the other appeal also.
